passages.text: F2Q Preview: Headwinds likely to persist, Establishing a \(\) 9\(PT Following Reverse Stock Split\) \frac{1}{2} \(\)

We model 2Q revenue of \(\) 97M\((\mathrm{vs.}\) consensus \(\) 96M\(and guide\) \ \(90 - 100M)\) and EBITDA loss of \(\) 24M\((\mathrm{vs.}\) consensus \(\) 21M\$ ). Our revenue estimates contemplate 2Q hardware revenue remaining fairly flat with 1Q, despite it being a historically stronger quarter due to seasonality, taking into account the mixed impacts of potential pre- buying in the first half of this year ahead of anticipated tax credit phase- outs or tariffs, which could result in incremental deliveries landing in 2Q, or, customers doubling down on pausing new orders due to a worse EV sales and market penetration outlook in the years to come. While we expect to eventually see revenue uplift from ChargePoint's channel partnership with Eaton, this is set to be more impactful from F3Q onward once the partnership is operationalized and new offerings are announced in the coming weeks. We expect gross margins to improve slightly on a sequential basis, though largely still weighted to the 2H of the year as existing inventory is sold through before we see the benefit of ChargePoint's new, lower- cost hardware roll through. Although management has remained committed to turning EBITDA breakeven exiting this year, this will largely depend on meaningful H/H revenue and margin growth; based on our calculations, ChargePoint would need to reach \(\sim\) 140M+ of revenue, \(20\% +\) hardware gross margins, and maintain relatively flat opex to achieve this on a run- rate basis in F4Q, which still feels highly ambitious to us. We think investors would be disappointed, but not surprised, if profitability guidance were to be withdrawn or postponed. We tweak our out- year estimates and remain below the Street throughout the course of our modeling period as we think the hardware- software EV charging providers will continue to face competitive pressures from commoditization, which could be worse for revenue growth and margin trajectory. We remain Underweight rated CHPT and establish a \(\) 9\(Dec 2026 price target after updating our estimates and accounting for the recent 1 - for - 20 reverse stock split.

2Q Market Backdrop: Read- throughs from other EV Charging players point to a mixed operating environment in 2Q, with Wallbox (WBX, not covered) citing the OBBB as creating uncertainty and Blink Charging (BLNK, not covered) primarily highlighting strength on the fast charging owner- operator side of the business, rather than hardware sales, which declined Y/Y. Our analysis of DOE data would reflect \(\sim 2,200\) public charging ports added to ChargePoint's US network during the quarter, which reflects a Y/Y improvement but a slight sequential decline.

We remain Underweight rated CHPT. Though there are green shoots on both the revenue and cost side for ChargePoint, we remain cautious around the path to profitability over the next several quarters, especially relative to owner- operator peers, which have more visibility around scaling up from here in our view. We expect many investors to remain sidelined given the slowing momentum in the charging industry.
CHPT, CHPT US Price (27 Aug 25): \(\) 11.46\(Price Target (Dec - 26):\) \ \(9.00\)

ChargePoint is one of the early players in the North American charging market, with leading market share in Level 2 and a growing share in DC Fast. However, as a hardware- software provider, the company has seen demand destruction in the muted EV demand environment given a pullback from commercial customers and limited activity with fleet customers, coupled with downsizing of its sales staff. We see the muted demand environment pressuring ChargePoint's top line, and despite measures to improve its cost basis by offshoring to Asia, we think ChargePoint's path to profitability remains less clear at this stage. We think there is further downside from here based on muted investor sentiment and unlikely market recovery.

We use a 1.5x EV/sales multiple and 10x EV/EBITDA multiple applied to FY29 values, when we expect the company to reach double- digit EBITDA scale, then discount back to Dec 2026 at \(12\%\) to reach our price target. This implies a slight premium to where the stock currently trades at on the sales side (currently trading at \(\sim 1x\) sales) given negativity in the EV value chain; however, it is in line with the stock's historical three- year trading average. The EBITDA multiple falls in line with the typical 10- 12x range of renewables infrastructure developers.

ChargePoint (Underweight; Price Target: \(\) 9.00\$

ChargePoint is one of the early players in the North American charging market, with leading market share in Level 2 and a growing share in DC Fast charging. However, as a hardware- software provider, the company has seen demand destruction in the muted EV demand environment given a pullback from commercial customers and limited activity with fleet customers, coupled with downsizing of its sales staff. We see the muted demand environment pressuring ChargePoint's top line, and despite measures to improve its cost basis by offshoring to Asia, we think ChargePoint's path to profitability remains less clear at this stage. We think there is further downside from here based on muted investor sentiment and unlikely market recovery.

We use a \(1.5x\) EV/Sales multiple and \(10x\) EV/EBITDA multiple applied to FY29 values, when we expect the company to reach double- digit EBITDA scale, then discount back to Dec 2026 at \(12\%\) to reach our price target. This implies a slight premium to where the stock currently trades at on the sales side (currently trading at \(\sim 1x\) sales) given negativity in the EV value chain; however, it is in line with the stock's historical three- year trading average. The EBITDA multiple falls in line with the typical \(10 - 12x\) range of renewables infrastructure developers.
Upside risks to our rating and price target include:

- The electric vehicle industry may grow at a faster pace than expected.- ChargePoint may be able to significantly grow its market share in the charging industry based on strong customer acquisition and retention.- Commercial and fleet demand may rebound sooner than expected.- Margin expansion could occur more quickly than expected, which could pull forward profitability.

For all Korea-based Research Analysts listed on the front cover, if applicable, they also certify, as per KOFIA requirements, that the Research Analyst's analysis was made in good faith and that the views reflect the Research Analyst's own opinion, without undue influence or intervention.

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website,
https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
